Proxenus gone into Asia, to take part with Cyrus; whether your designes will prosper God knowes, they are here condemned by many, for it is conceived unfit the Athenians should assist Cyrus, through whose means they were deprived of command by the Lacedaemonians and fight for him, who fought against them. It is not therefore strange if the state being altered, some be ready of themselves to accuse you of temporising, and the better your successe is, the greater will be their calumnies; for I am well acquainted with the dispositions of some of them: But since we have undertaken this, let us prove our selves honest men, and call to mind what we use to say of vertue, accounting this one of the best sentences of the Poet, Our Fathers house must not be discredited. Know therefore, that to war, these two are requisite, Courage an Bounty, for this, we are loved of our friends, for that, feared of our enemies, of both, thou hast domestick precedents.

div.head: Epist. VI.
div.p: I Have taken such care of your strangers as you desired, & retained one to plead their cause before the people,Perhaps Lysias. a friend of ours, who profest himselfe the readier to undertake it, out of his desire to serve thee.

As for that which you write in jest concerning wealth, and such as are sollicitous for it, perhaps it is not unreasonable. First, because whilst others study to be rich, I choose to live meanly. Then though I might receive many gifts and legacies from living and dead friends; yet I freely disclaim them, and for a man thus enclined to be by others judged mad, is nothing strange: But we must examine not this onely, but the rest of
our life; and since we disagree in the use, no wonder that wee differ in the acquisition of
〈◊〉
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 read 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Riches; my diet is very sparing, my habit the same in winter as in summer: I never wear shoes, I am not taken with Popular applause, but with the study of wisdom and integrity. But they who are intemperarate, Luxurious in meat, not every year, but every day putting on new apparell are transported with unlawfull delights, and as they who lose their naturall complexion have recourse to paint. So these losing the true glory of virtue which every one ought to have, flie to that which depends upon complaisance with others, courting vulgar applause with Largesses and feasts. Hence I suppose it comes, that they need much wealth; They themselves cannot live upon a little, nor will others adm ••
them into their society, unlesse they receive a salary for commending them.

But my life is well as to both these, I will not deny but in some things I may fail, I know that wisest men prefer those, most men these; Reflecting sometimes within my selfe upon God; I find that he exceeds us, in that he hath need of nothing; it is the property of a most excellent nature not to want any thing, and to comprehend within himself all that he enjoyes. Thus is he wiser then others, who imitates the most wise
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
and happier, who resembles the most happy. If riches could do this, riches were to be preferr'd; but since vertue only can obtain it, it were folly to forsake the reall good to pursue the seeming. Hence I cannot easily be perswaded but that my Condition is better then the • rs.

As for children, who as you say ought to be provided for, the care that I take for them all men may see, I know but one ground of hapinesse, wisdom. The fool who reposeth his trust in gold, possesseth not that which he hath, and is withall so much more miserable then others, in that they who are opprest with poverty may grow wise hereafter. But he out of an opinion of his own happinesse, neglecting true gain corrupted with plenty.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
〈…〉 . Besides that he never yet obtained, mans essentiall good is depriv'd of hope thereof for the future. Nor is it possible that such a man can go on securely to virtue, who is entangled in the slatteries of those who are Masters in all insinuating Arts, and in the Charms of pleasures which glide into the soul through every sense, and drive out all sound and wise judgement. How then can hee choose but give his Childre occasion of folly rather then instruction,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 &c. which 〈◊〉 , reading immediately after for 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . who not only in words but actions expresseth that in these things she hath placed his hope, who not proving good, their subsistence fails, and they die miserably for want of food: Justly punish'd for their idlenesse; Parents are by Law enjoyned to bring up their children till they are men. But you, perhaps some Citizen may say to his
Sonnes greedy to inherit, spare me not dying, and whilst you live relie for maintenance upon me, though dead not ashamed to lead a life more lazy then death; you expect that my fortunes should extend to others even after my decease, but your own are not competent for your selves whilest you are yet alive. Such rough speeches happily he will use to his Children, taking the libery both of a Father and a Patriot. My fortunes in the estimate of other men are mean, but in the effect nothing inferior to the Rich. I will not leave my Children money, but a more honorable heritage, discreet friends, whom as long as they keep they can want as necessaries, and if they use them ill, doubtlesse they would use their money worse.

But if to you, who know the negligence of friends, I seem to give ill advice; I answer, that all men are not alike affected to their friends, for some take care of them after they are dead, and it is likely that ours are not of a neglectfull humour, but pleas'd with the past advantage they have received by us, no lesse then with the present of a short benefit, the requitall is short; lasting benefits produce a return equall to their profit, and I foresee that what is mine, will hereafter appear more gracious to my friends, and therefore I exact no rewards of them. I account nothing of equal value in exchange with Philosophy but friendship, nor like the Sophists have I any diffidence of those things that are mine, for being old they renew, and in their decaying agePe • haps 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . So Allatius seems to read. flourish, which makes them more acceptable to the Disciples, and their Father more esteemed; For 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 reading 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Living he obtains honour, dead is thought worthy of memory, and if he leave an Kinsman behind him, they will respect him like his Nephewes and Brethren, and show him all kindnesse, as being allied to him by more then a Naturall affinity; Neither if they would, can they neglect him in misfortunes, no more then we can slight them, who are near to us in blood; for affinity in soul forceth them to relieve the Son of the dead as if he were their own brother; when they call to mind his Father, whose dishonour they account their own.

Now judge if I order my affairs ill, or take no care for my Children, so as when I die they shall be destitue of necessaries, who leave them not wealth but such Guardians as will have a care of them and wealth No History makes mention of any man that hath been made better by riches; A tried friend in this is to be preferr'd before tried gold, that he is not beneficiall to every one who desires him, but to those he lovse best. Nor doth he supply onely the necessities of life, but is serviceable as well to the soul of him that hath him, and is most conducing to virtue, without which nothing profieth; but we will consider more exactly upon these things when we meet; thus much serve as a cursory answer to your demand.

div.head: Epist VII.
div.p: I Wonder not at what you write, that you do suspect the Thirty continue the same mind to us since your departure, which they had when you were here. As soon as you were gone, they began to have a jealousie of me, and there past amongst them a murmure that these things were not done without Socrates; within few daies they cited me to the Court, where some complaints were preferr'd against me, and when I defended my self, they commanded me to go to the Pyraeum to apprehend Leon, their intention was to put him to death, that they might enjoy his estate, and make me partner in their injustice; when I refused, and said something to this effect that I would never willingly subscribe to an unjust act; Charicles was present, and inwardly vext, Socrates saith he, dost thou think to talk thus peremptorily, and not suffer ten thousand ills? Charicles, said I, but none so hainous as to do unjustly. Hee answered not a word, nor any of the rest, but ever since they have liked me the worse.

As for you, some that were then present, reported that your affairs succeed to your wish, that the Thebans in your exile received you kindly, and will assist your return to their utmost. Some were troubled at this news, and the more because it lessen'd their hopes of supply from Lacedaemon, for they who came along with the Ambassadours, affirmed, that the Lacedaemonians were engaged in a great war, and the Ephori hearing of those troubles, were discontented, and said, that the Lacedaemonians had not intrusted with the City to see it destroy'd; Perhaps. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 &c. for if they would have done so, it were most easie for them who had the Command, being withall instigated therunto by the Corinthians and Thebans, and that the City might be better govern'd under an Oligarchy then a Democracy. If all this be true, and your affairs succeed as they report, there is great likely hood that upon you, coming in with the Thebans, the Lacedaemonians not aiding these, all things here may be easily composed. Besides, many of the Natives who now are quiet through fear, if they perceived never so little that you were firme, will readily forsake this party, because in this government of the City, nothing is left them entire, but through many and continuall enormities all is in confusion; the greater part is revolted as well as you, the rest if they had the least encouragement from abroad would suffer the same that you have. So that if no other, yet this example would manifest that
the greatest unhappinesse of Cities is the wickednesse of their Rulers, for they are so blinded with self interest that they will not desist, though they see all things go to ruine, but with what they first troubled, think to settle affairs, continuing banishments, sequestrations, and unjust deaths; not considering he is an ill Physician who prescribes for a Remedy the cause of the disease. But those are incurable; you shall doe well to have a care of your self, for all that are here have but this hope left, if you act wisely to be freed from a heavy and grievous Tyranny.

div.head: THE CLOVDS of Aristophanes.
Added (not as a Comicall divertisement for the Reader, who can expect little in that kind from a subject so antient, and particular, but) as a necessary supplement to the life of Socrates.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: OH, oh,
Great Iove, how long a night is this, how endlesse!
Will't neer be day? I heard the Cock again,
Yet still my servants snore; 'tis but of late

They durst do thus:The Athenians in time of war with the Lacedaemonians made an Edict, that no man should beat his servants, lest they should go over to the enemy. Schol. curse o' this war that awes me,
And will not suffer me to beat the Rogues.
My good Son sleeps too, wrapt ore head and ears:
Well, let me try to bear them company;
Alasse, I cannot, so perplext and tortur'd
With charges, bills for Horse-meat, interest:
All for this hopefull Son, who in's curl'd locks,
Aides matches, keeps his Coach, and dreames of Horses,
Whilst I (unhappy!) see th' unwelcome Moon
Bring on the Quarter day, and threaten use-mony.
Boy, snuffe the light, bring my account book hither,
That I may summe my debts and interest:
Let's see, twelve pound to Pasia; ha! twelve pound
To Pasia, how laid out? to buyTheir horses were named from the marks they had; if a K. Ceppatia; if an an S, Samphor • . Schol. Coppatia:
Would I had paid this eye for him.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: Hold Philo,
You'r out of the way, begin again.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: I this,
This is the misery that ruines me;
His very sleeps are taken up with Horses.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: How many courses will the manage hold.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Many a weary course thou leads thy Father:
But how much more owe I then this to Pasia?
Three pound t' Amynias for Chariot wheeles.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: Go sirrah, take that horse and turn him out.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: I thou hast turned me out of all my means,
Charges at Law will eat me up, my Creditours
Threaten to sue me to an execution.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: Why do you wake all night, and tosse so Father?

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: I cannot sleep, the Scrivener doth so bite me.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: Yet let me rest a little longer.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Do so.
All these will one day light upon thy head,
Curs'd be the houre when I first saw thy Mother,
I liv'd before most sweetly in the Country,
Well stock't with Sheep and Bees, Olives and Grapes,
Till from the Megaclean house I took
This Neece of Megacles out of the City,
Well fashion'd, highly bred, and richly cloathed;
We married, as I said: and lay together:
I sinelling strong of Drugs and greasie Wool;
But she of Unguents, Crocus wanton Kisses,
Of vain expence, dainties, and luxury;
I will not tell the idle life she led,
And yet she spun that I have often told her,

Showing this Coat,
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 Sch. MS. you spin a fair thread woman.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Sir, all the Oyle ith' Lamp is wasted.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Ha?
Why didst thou put in such a Drunken week?
If thou wert neer me I would beat thee.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Why Sir?

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Because the week is thicker then the oyl.
Well, at last my good Wife and I betwixt us got
At last this Son; about his name we differ'd;
Shee'd have it something that belong'd to horses,
Callippides, Xanthippus, or Charippus;
I from his Grandfather) Phidontdes.
Long time we wrangled thus, at last agreed
He should be called Phidippides; this Son
She takes, and stroaking kindly, thus instructs him,
"When thou art grown a man, frequent the City,
"Follow the fashion, keep a Coach and Horses,
"Like Megacles thy Uncle. No, said I,
"Go in a homely Coat, and drive thy Goats
"IntoA stony craggy place in Attica, in such Goats delight most. Soli. M. S: Phelleus, as they father doth.
But my advice prevailed so little on him,
That now he wasts my means in keeping horses,
Which all this night I have been thinking how
To remedy, and now have found the way;
To which could I perswade him, I were happy.
Phidippides, Phidippides,

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: Your will Sir.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Kisse me, give me thy hand.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: Here Sir.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Dost love me?

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: By Neptune God of Horses.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Do not name
That God, for 'tis from him springs all my sorrow:
But if thou lov'st me truly, heartily,
O son be rul'd.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: In what should I be rul'd?

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Change without more delay thy course of life,
And do • as I would have thee.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: What is that?

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: But wilt thou do it?

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: Yes by Bacchus will I.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Come hither then, seest thou that little dore?

That is the
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 Schol. M. S. Ph • ontistherium of wise soules,
Of learned men, that tell us Heaven's an Oven,
And we the Coles inclosed in the wide arch:
They, if we give 'em but a little mony,
Will teach us gain all causes, right or wrong.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: Who can these be?

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Their names I know not; good
They are, and busied in continuall study.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: Oh now I know the wretches that you mean,
The meager, wan, proud, bare-foot, begging fellowes,
Whose evill Geniuss's are Socrates
And Chaerephon.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Peace, talk no more so idly;
If you'l obey a father, let me see you
Give ore your horses, and turn one of these.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: Not I, by Bacchus, no though you should tempt me

With all
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 Schol. M. • . Leogoras his breed of Racers.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Dear son be rul'd and learn.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: What should I learn?

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: 'Tis said they have two tongues, and one of them
Able to prove any injustice reason;
Couldst thou but learn that language, we were made,
And might dispute our stubborn Creditours
Out of the debts I have incurr'd for thee;
They get not then a penny more then words.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: I cannot do't, were I so lean and Pale,
I durst not look a Jocky in the face.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: By Ceres then you stay with me no longer,
You, nor your Coach-horse, nor your Samphoras,
But all together pack out of my dores.
My Uncle Megacles will neither see
Me nor my horses want, so long I care not.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: THough I have fail'd, i'l not give over thus,
But say my prayers, and go my self to school
To learn this Art: but how can I, by Age
Dull and forget full, reach such subtleties?
Yet on I will, why should I doubt? ho, friend.

sp.speaker: Sc • ol.
sp.l: A mischief on you, who's that knocks at dore?

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Strepsiades, Cecinnian Phaedo's Son.

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: 'T was rudely done to knock so hard, y'have made
My labouring brain miscarry of a Notion.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Forgive me, I was bred far off ith' Country:
But pray what notion was't that prov'd abortive?

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: 'Tis lawfull to discover that tonone
But fellow-scholars.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Then you may tell me,
For I come hither to be one of you.

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: I will; so will value't as a mysterie.
Socrates t'other day ask'd Chaerephons eyebrow,
And leap'd from thence upon the head of Socrates.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: How could he measure this?

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: Most dexterously.
Both feet oth' flea he dipt in melting wax,
Which strait congeals to shooes; these he plucks off,
And with them most exactly measures it.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Great Iupiter, how subtle are these wits!

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: If you shouldst hear their other speculations,
You would say so indeed.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Pray what was that?

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: This Charaephon the Sphettian ask'd him once,
If a Gnat sounded from her mouth or tail.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: And what said he?
It had a strait thin gut,
At end of it a bladder, into which
The air being forc'd, sounded in breaking forth.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Then I perceive that a gnat's tail's a Trumpet;
How blest is this Anatomist of Gnats!
Sure he can hide himself from purblind justice,
That knows so well these dark intestine waies.
Why should we cry up Thales any longer?
Come open me your Phrontisterium,
And quickly let me see this Socrates,
I long to learn, open the dore—The School discovered; the Schollars in severall postures: Socrates hanging in a basket. O Hercules
What strange beasts have we here!

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: Why do you wonder?
Whom do they look like think you?

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Like the poor
Lacedaemonian Captives tane atSuid. lib. Pylus.
Why look they so intently on the ground?
These seek out things that appertain to Earth!
Oh they seek leeks; trouble your selves no more friends,
For I know better where are good and great ones.

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: Come let's go in.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Let's stay a while and talk with 'em.

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: No, no, they cannot long endure the air.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: What's this, for Heavens sake say?

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: This is Astronomy.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: And this?

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: Geometry.

sp.speaker: Strop.
sp.l: But what is't good for?

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: To measure land.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: What, arable or pasture?

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: No, the whole Earth.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: A pretty jest indeed.
That were a mighty help to husbandmen.

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: Here's all the world, and this is Athens.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: How?
I'l scarce believe that, what's become oth' Judges?
Where the Cicynians my Countymen?

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: Here; this Eubaea; see how far 'tis stretch'd.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: I, almost stretch'd in pieces betwixt us,
And Pericles; and where is Lacedaemon?

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Strepss.
sp.l: 'Tis too nigh us, why, with all your skill
Do you not help to thrust it farther off.

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: It is not possible.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: No? you will rue't then.
But what man's that hangs yonder in the basket?

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: That's he.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: He, what he?

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: Socrates.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: How, Socrates?
Call him.

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: Call him your self, I'm not at leasure.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: HO Socrates

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: The words of Silenus (whom Socrates resembled for deformity) in Pindar. Schol. Why dost thou call me mortall?

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: First I would gladly know what thou dost there?

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: I walk ith' aire, and gaze upon the Sun.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Why in a basket dost thou view the Gods,
Not from the ground?

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: I could not elevate
My thoughts to contemplation of these mysteries,
Unlesse my Intellect were thus suspended,
Where my thin thoughts melt into air (their likeness)
Stood I upon the ground, I should find nothing,
Though I sought nere so strictly up and down,
For the magnetick vertue of the Earth
Would draw away the humour of my brain,
Just as we see in nose-smart.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: How, hows that?
Doth the brain draw the humour out of nose-smart?
Come down sweet Socrates, and teach me quickly
The knowledge of those things for which I came.

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: What camest thou for?

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: To learn the art of speaking,
With debts and usury I'm torn in pieces
Tost up and down; forc'd to pawn all my goods:

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: On what occasion did you run in debt?

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: By horses eaten into this consumption;
And I would learn of you your other language
Which teacheth men to pay nothing: for which
By all the Gods i'l give you what you'l ask.

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: By all what Gods? we do not here allow
Those Gods the City worships.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: How then swear you,
By copper farthings like the Byzantines?

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: Wouldst thou be skilfull in divine affairs.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: By Iovr (if any such there be) I would.

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: You must be then acquainted with the Clouds,
Our reverend Goddesses.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: Sit down upon this Couch then

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: Now take
This Garland.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Why a garland? alasse Socrates,
D'ee mean (like Athamas) to sacrifice me?

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: No, these are rites that every one performes
At his admission.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: But what shall I gain by't?

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: Thou shallt be made most voluble in speech,
A very rattle, bolting words as fine
As flower.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Th'art right by Iove, I shall be powderd.

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: silenced old man, and listen to our prayer.
"Great King, unbounded air, whose armes are hurld
"About the surface of this pendant world,
"Bright Aether, reverend Clouds, that from your Sphear
"Thunder and lightning dart, rise and appear.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Not yet, not yet, till I have wrapt my selfe
Close in my Cloak, lest I be wet: twas ill
That I forgat to bring my Riding hood.

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: "Your power, great Clouds, make to this suppliant known
"Whether now seated on Olympus Throne,
"Or whether you your sacred revells keep
"In the wide Gardens of your Sire the deep:
"Or of his flowing Christall seaven-mouth'd Nile,
"In golden Ewers wantonly beguile:
"Or in Mauritian marshes keep your Court;
"Or on the snowy top of Mimas sport.
"Come, to our servant vowes propitious be;
"Grace with your presence our solemnitie.
"We humid fleeting Deities,
"The bright unbounded clouds thus rise
"From our old Sire, the grumbling Flood,Chorus of clouds.
"Above the tallest hill or wood,
"To those high watch-towers, whence we may
"The hallowed fruitfull-ground survey;
"Rivers that in soft murmurs glide,
"And the lowd sea's rebellious tide;
"From thence heavens restlesse eye displaies
"The splendour of his glorious raies,
"Chasing all dusky mists, that we
"In shapes divine may mortalls see.

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: Thanks reverend Clouds for favouring thus our prayer.
Did you not hear 'm speak in Thunder to us?

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Great Clouds, I worship too, but am so frighted,
I scarce can hold from answering your Thunder.

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: Jest not profanely in such sacred rites:
Peace, for the swarm of Goddesses come singing.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.l: "Come virgin Mistresses of showers,
"Let's visit Pallas pregnant bowers,
"The far renowned Cecropian plain

"Where shines the
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . at Eleusis in Attica were celebrated the my • eries of Ceres, to which Athenians only were admitted, not strangers; if any one dis covered them to a person not initiated, they were both put to death. Schol. M. S▪
Eleusinian Fane,
"Where are the most retir'd aboads,
"Statues and Temples of the Gods:
"Where Altars blaze with Incense, where
"The holy-day lasts all the year;
"Where the brisk Craces every spring,
"And youths with virgins dance and sing.

sp.speaker: Str • pe.
sp.l: Tell me good Socrates, what things are these
That speak so sinely? are they Ladies?

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: No,
They're Clouds, the Deities of idle men;
From these we have our sense, discourse, and reason,
Our high Capriccio's, and elaborate whimseys.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: My soul, me thought, did leap, while they were speaking,
And now most subtly would dispute of smoak,
Sharply confute opinion with opinion:
Oh how I long to see them once again.

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: Look yonder towards Parnes, look how gently
They glide to earth.

sp.speaker: Stre • s.
sp.l: Where? show me.

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: See in sholes
They creep into the Caverns of the Mountain.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: What things are these? I cannot yet behold'em.

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: There in the entrance look.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Yet I scarce see them.

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: Either thou seest them now, or thou art blind.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: I do by Iove, great Clouds, for you hold all •

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: Didst thou not know these Deities before?

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Not I, I thought them only mists and vapours:

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: Thou knewest not then those who maintain the Sophists.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: If these be Clouds, how comes it that they look
Like women? for the Clouds have no such shape.

sp.speaker: Srce.
sp.l: No, what shape have they then?

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: I know not justly;
They look like flying fleeces, but by Iove,
Nothing at all like women; these have noses.

sp.speaker: Socr.

l.note: The Socratick way of dispute by question.

sp.l: Answer to what I ask.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Ask me quickly.

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: Didst ere behold a Cloud shap'd like a Centaure,
A Leopard, Bull, or Wolfe?

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: I have, what then?

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: The Clouds can take what form they list, as when
They see a hairy fellow curl'd like Clitus,
They mock his madnesse in a Centaures shape.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: And when they see one that defrauds or plunders
The Common-wealth, like Sinon, what then do they?

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: They do resemble him, turn ravenous wolves,
This was the reason yesterday, when they
BeheldCoward. Cleonymus, they fled like deer:
And seeingE •• eminately attired. Clisth • nes are now turn'd women.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Great Queens, if you ere design to speak to mortalls,
Make me acquainted with your rumbling voice.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.l: "All hail old man, who dost on wisdome prey,
"And thou the Priest of subtle trifles say,
"What wouldst thou have with us, to none but thee,
"Of all the Meteor Sophists thus stoop we;

"Save
• rodicus, to him as grave and wise,
"To thee, because thou walkst upright, thy eye •
"Rowling on every side, thy look severe
"And barefoot many miseries dost bear.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Good heavens, what voice is this, how strange & stately.

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: These are our Goddesses▪ the rest are toyes.

sp.speaker: Streps,
sp.l: Is then Olympian Iove no Deity?

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: What Iove? there's no such thing; meer fancy.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: How?

Whence then proceeds allWhereof Iupiter was the particular Deity; thence sirnamed 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
rain?

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: Only from these.
Didst thou ere see a shower without them? take
The Clouds away, and heaven must rain fair weather.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: By Phoebus thou hast cleer'd it well, till now
I thought Iove made water through a • ive.
But whence comes thunder? when I'me sick, that frights me,
These thunder as they tumble up and down.
How can that be?

sp.speaker: Socr.

l.note: Deriding Socrates as ignorant in Naturall Philosophy.

sp.l: When they are full of water,
By their won weight, driven upon one another,
They roar and break.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: But who is it that drives them,
Is not that Iove?

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: No, an aetheriall whirlewind.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: A whirle-wind, hum! I knew not that til now.
But whence comes lightning then, that glittering fire
Which terrifies and burns us? Iupiter
Useth to dart this down on perjur'd men.

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: And how (thou phlegmatick, dull Saturnine,)
If darted on the perjur'd, how comes Sinon,
Theorus, and Cleonymus to scapeit?
No, his own Temple, or the Sunian Promontory,
Or sturdy Oakes he strikes, did they ere wrong him?
Did the Oak ere forswear it selfe?

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: I know not:
That which you say seems reason; but what then
Is lightning?

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: When the winds are shut up close,
They swell the clouds like bladders, and at last
Break out with violence and horrid noises;
And by contrition kindle one another.
But thou who searchest amongst us for wisdom,
How happy wilt thou be above all Graecians
If thou conceive well, and remember, and
Canst suffer much, and never wilt be tir'd
Standing or walking, nor have sense of frost,
Nor care for dyning, and refrain from wine,
From exercises, and all other toyes.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: O for a solid soul restlesse with cares,
Sparing, self-torturing, one that can feast
Upon a dish of herbes, you never could
Be better • itted; a meer an vile I.

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: Dost thou believe no Gods but those we teach,
The Chaos, Clouds and Tongue, onely these three.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: I'l not so much as speak of any other,
Much lesse bestow an offering on their Altars.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.l: "Say boldy then, say what is thy request,
"For if thou honour us thou shalt be blest.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Great Queens I sue for a small matter, that
I may out-talk all Greeks a hundred furlongs.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.l: To thee alone this gift we will allow,
None speak such mighty sentences as Thou.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: I do not care for mighty sentences,
But subtle ones to cheat my Creditours.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.l: It is not much thou askst, and shalt obtain it,

l.q: Learn of our Ministers and thou shalt gain it.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: I shall, relying on your promise; forc'd
By want, Co • patia and a lucklesse match.
Now let'em use me as they list, beat, starve me,
Burn, freeze, or flea me, so I scape my debts:
I care not though men call me impudent,
Smooth-tongu'd, audacious, petulant▪ abhominable,
Forger of words and lie, contentious Barretour,
Old, winding, bragging, testy, crafty fox.

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: Said like a man of courage; if thou learn
Of me, thy fame shall spread wide as the Heavens▪

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: Thou shalt spend all thy time
With me; a life the happiest in the world.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: I long to see that day.

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: Thy dore shall alwaies
Be throng'd with Clients that will come to thee
For Counsell, and discourse of cases worth
The wealth of kingdoms, to thy h • arts desire.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.l: "Try this old man; first see if he be sit;
"Put him toth' test, and sound the depth of's wit.

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: Come tell me now your disposition,
That when I know it I may sit my Machines
Accordingly.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: You will not undermine me.

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: No, I would know if you have any memory.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Yes, when another owes me any thing,
I can remember very well, but what
I owe my self, i'm ready to forget.

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: Hast thou a naturall faculty in speaking

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: No, I can mar words sooner far then make'em.

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: How wilt thou learn then?

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Fear me not, I tell you
Wel, when I make some learned deep discourse.

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: As the Schollers of Socrates used, especially Xenephon and Plato. You must be sure to catch't up presently.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: What must I snap at learning like a dog?

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: This is a very fool, an unknown Clown;
I am afraid old man thou wilt need whipping.
What if thou shouldst be beaten?

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Then i'm beaten.

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: But what wouldst do?

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: I would take witnesse on't
And sue them on an action of Battery.

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: Off with your Cloak.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Why, how have I offended?

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: No; but our orders admit none but naked.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: I came not hither to steal any thing.

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: Down with your Cloak, why dost thou trifle.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Now
Tell me if I prove apt and diligent,
Of all your schollars who shall I come nighest?

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: Thou maist perhaps be like our Chaerephon.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Alasse, alasse! what an Anatomy?

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: No, no: but if thou wilt be any thing,
Follow me without more delay.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: I want
A Cake for your Cerberus; I go me thinks
As if 'twere into the Trophonian Cave.

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: On, on, why stayst thou gazing at the dore.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.l: "Go, for thy courage blest whose aged mind
"To wisdom soars, and leaves the young behind.

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: BY Chaos, and this air I breath, I never
Met any thing so stupid as this fellow,
So clownish and oblivious; easie toyes
He learns, not half so fast as he forgets'em,
I'l call him forth; what, ho, Strepsiades;
Come out and bring your bed along with you.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: The fleas will hardly let me bring my self.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Quick, down with't there; and mark what I say to you.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: I'm ready.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: What have you most mind to learn,
Measures, or Verse, or Rhyme?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: By all means measures;
For I was cheated by a Meal-man lately
Two pecks.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: That's not the thing I demand;
I'de know • which you conceive the fairest measure.
The Trimeter or the Tetrameter.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: The fairest measure in my mind's a Bushell.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: 'Tis nothing that you say.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: What will you lay
That your Tetrameter holds not a Bushell.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Away, away, how dull thou art, and blockish,
But thou wilt be perhaps more apt at Rime.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: What help can rimes afford me in my meal.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: First they wil make thee pleasant in all company.
Then thou shalt know which suits with Anapaestick,
And which with Dactyles.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Dactiles? I know that sure.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Why what's a Dactyle.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: What but this same • inger,
• Thas been a Dactyle ere since I was a child.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Th'art an unprofitable Dunce.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: I care not
For learning these devices.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: What then wouldst thou?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: That, that unjust and cheating Sophistry.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: But there are things that must be learnt before
You come to that; what Creatures are there Masculine.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Sure I know that or I were mad indeed.
A Ram, a Bull, a Goat, a Dog, a Pigeon.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Deriding Socrates a • ignorant in Grammer. See how thou err'st, that call'st both male and female
A Pigeon.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Right, by Neptune, how then must I?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Call this a Cock-Pigeon, and that a Hen.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: A Pigeon, Cock and Hen, ha! by this air,
For this sole document, I will replenish
YourA meal-trough the Greek word hath a Masculine termination but feminine article. Cardopus with meal.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Again th'art wrong;
Thou call'st it Cardopus, but 'tis haec Cardopus,
And therefore henceforth call it Cardopa.
Next it is fit you know which names are Masculine,
And which are feminine.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: I know well which
Are feminine, I'me sure.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Lets hear.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Philina,
Cletagora, Demetria, and Lystha.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: And which are Masculine?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: A world, Philoxenus,
Milesias, and Amynias.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Thou art out.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Are not these Masculine with you?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Esseminate Cowards. By no means.
How if you saw Amynias, would you call him?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Amynia, ho!

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: What, make a woman of him.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: And reason good, h'has thrown away his armes,
And will not • ight, But to what purpose learn I
These common trifles.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Not so common neither,
But come, lie down.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: What must I do?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Consider
With your selfe the businesse that concernes you.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Not in this bed, I thank you, if I must
Lie down, Ile meditate upon the ground.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: But heres no room besides.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Wretch that I am.
How I shall be tormented with these • leas!

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Now think into the depth of thy affairs,
Try every turn and winding, every double;
And if you stick at any thing: give't ore,
And to some other; but be sure you sleep not,

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Oh, oh.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: How now the matter?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: I am kill'd
By these blood-suckers, these Corinthians.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Do not torment your selfe.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: How can I choose
When I have neither mony left, nor colour,
Scarce life, no shooes, grown almost to a Ghost
With watching?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Now what think y'on, nothing?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Yes
By Neptune.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: I'me thinking if the fleas
Will leave a piece of me or not.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Death on thee.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: You might have spar'd your curse, I'm dead already.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Fy, fy, you must not be so tender,So Socrates disputes in • lato's Phadrus, that exteriour objects might not divert him; which Aristophanes here derides. cover
Your face, and study for some subtle cheat.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Would I could learn to cheat these wicked fleas.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Let's see what does he? what, asleep, ha'ye thought
Of nothing yet?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: What would you have me think on?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: What would you learn?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: I've told you that already
A thousand times; I'd learn to pay no use-mony.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Come then, cover your self, and subtilize
Your thoughts, dissect your businesse into Atomes.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Alasse.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Ly still; and if you stick at any thing,
Passe by't a while, and come to it again.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Ho, my dear Socrates.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: What is't old man?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: I have found out that will do't.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: As how.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: First tell me
Where I may meet with some Thessalian witch;
For I would steal the Moon one of these nights,
And having got her, lock her in a chest
As charily, as I would keep a glasse.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: What wilt thou get by that?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: What, if the Moon
Ne'r rise again, I'me bound to pay no use.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: How so?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: 'Cause use you know is paid by th'Month,

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: 'Tis well, but I'le propound another businesse;
Suppose that you were tyed upon a statute
To pay five Talents, could you rase figures?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: I know not, but I'le try.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: You must not limit
Your thoughts so narrowly within your selfe,
But like a beetle fetter'd in a thread,
Allow them play and flutter in the air;

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: I ha't, I ha't, the rarest way to cancell
A deed, as you'l confesse when you have heard it.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: What iis't?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Did you nere see at any Grocers
A clear transparant stone, with which they use
To kindle fire?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: You mean a burning-glasse.

sp.speaker: Stro.
sp.l: The very same.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: What wouldst thou do with it?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Whilst that the Scrivener writes the deed, d'ee mark,
Thus standing by him with my burning glasse
Against the Sun, I'l burn out every letter.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Wisely by all the Graces.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: How I long
To cancell thus a bond of fifty pound.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: 'Tis well, now tell me if thy adversary
Sue thee, and thou art like to be orethrown
For want of witnesses, how wilt thou 'void
His suit.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Most easily.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Which way?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Before
It comes to judgement, I would hang my self.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Push, thou sayst nothing.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Yes, by love there's none
Will prosecute a suit against the dead.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Away, thou fool'st; i'l teach no more.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Why dear Socrates,
Why?

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Thou forget'st as fast as thou canst learn.
Tell me the first thing thou wert taught to day:

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: The first, stay let me see; the first thing say you?
How call you that we use to put our meal in?
Wretch, Iv'e forget it!

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: See, deserv'st thou not
Forget full to be punish'd for a dunce.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Alasse what shall I do? for if I learn not
The cheating language, I am quite undone:
Good Clouds advise me what course I shall take.

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: "If an ingenious son thou hast at home,
"Thou hadst best send him hither in thy room.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: I have a son, and he's ingenious too;
But will not learn, the more my misery.

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: And wilt thou suffer't?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Of a promising person
His mother is a woman of great spirit;
Once more Ile try; if he refuse, i'I make
No more adoe but turn him out of dores;
Stay but a while, I will be quickly back.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: NOw by the Clouds thou staist no longer here?
Hence, and go feed in Megacles his stable.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Alasse what fury hath possest you Father?
By Iove I think you are besides your self.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: See, see, he swears by Iove, art thou not mad
At these years to believe there is a Iove?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Is truth to be derided?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Well I see
Th'art still a Child and credit'st old wives tales.
But come I will tell thee that shall make thee
A man, so you be sure to tell it no body.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Pretty; what is't?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Thou swor'st e'en now by Iove.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: I did so.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: See how good it is to learn;
There's no such thing as Iove.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: A whirlwind
Hath blown Iove quite away and rules all Heaven.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: What fooleries are these?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: They're serious truth son.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Who tells you so?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: And Chaerephon, that trace the steps of fleas.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: How, are you grown to such a height of madness,
As to believe such melancholy dreamers.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Good words: defame not men of such deep wisdom
And subtle spirits; these live sparingly,
Are never at the charges of of a Barber,
Unguents, or Baths, whereas thou wasts my means
As freely as if I were dead already.
Come then, and be their scholler in my room.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: What can be learnt that's good of such as they are?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: All things that are accompted wisdom Boy;
And first to know thy self, and what a dunce
Thou art, how blockish, rustick and forgetfull.
But stay a little, cover thy face a while.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Alasse my fathers mad, what shall I do,
Accuse him to the Court of folly,
Be speak a Coffin for him, for he talks
Idly, as he were drawing on?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Come on now.
Let's see, what that?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: A Pigeon.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Good; and that?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: A Pigeon.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Both the same? ridiculous.
Take heed you make not such mistakes hereafter.
This you must call a Cock, and that a Hen.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: A Hen? Is this the goodly learning Father
You got since your admission 'mongst these earth-wormes?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: This and a great deal more; but being old,
I soon forget what I am taught.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: I think
'Twas want of memory made you lose your cloak.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: No, 'tis hung up upon the arts and sciences;

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: And where your shooes?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Lost for the common good,
Like Pericles: But lets be gone and see
You learn t'obey me, and to wrong all else.
Remember that I bought thee, when thou wert
But six yeers old, a little Cart to play with.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Alasse you'l be the first that will repent this.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Take you no care for that; do as I bid you.
Ho, Socrates, I've brought my son at last,
Though much against his will.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: I, that's because
He's rude, untaught, a child of ignorance,
And unacquainted with our hungry baskets.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Go hang your self in one of them.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: How impudence; dost thou talk thus to thy Master?

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: So go hang, with what a seeming grace was that pronounc'd!
How do you think that he should ever learn
To overthrow a nimble adversary,
Or win a Judges heart with Rhetorick?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Fear not, but teach him; he's ingenious
By Nature; for when he was but a little one,
Hee'd build you houses, and make leather Coaches,
And ships, and cut frogs out of apple parings.
What's your opinion then? do you not think
Hee's capable to learn both languages?
Or if not both, be sure he learn the worse.

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: Well, we shall try what may be done with him,

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Farewell, and so remember that in all
I say that's just, you learn to contradict me.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: THeFrom the twentieth day of the month they reckon'd backward, see the life of Solons Chap. fift, the fourth, the third, the seconds, hum.
The most abhord and dreadfull day's at hand,
The old and new; all I ow money to
Threaten to sue and vow my utter ruine;
Yet I require nothing but what is just reason:
My friend forbear me till some other times;
But they all answer me, words are no payment,
Revile me, swear they'l put their bonds in suit,
And let'em, what care I, so my Phidippides
Have learnt the art of cheating: I shall know straight;
It is but knocking at the school, ho son.

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: SAve you Strepsiades.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: The like to you.
Such guif • s Socrates sometimes accepted, though not money. See Chap. First take this bag of meal, for it is fit
We pay our duty to our reverend Master,
Now tell me, has my son attain'd the art
For which I plac'd him with you.

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: Yes exactly.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Thanks to deceit, the Queen that governs all things.

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: Now you may overthrow all adversaries.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: What though a witnesse swear that I have borrowed.

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: I though a thousand swear't.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Iò. Iò.
Triumph my boyes, wo to you money-mongers,
You and your bonds, your use on use may hang now,
You'l trouble me no more! O what a son
Have I, that senceth with a two-edg'd tongue,
My Houses prop and Guardian, my foes terrour,
Quickly come forth, and meet my glad embraces,
Come forth and hear thy Father.

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: See the man.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: O my dear boy!

sp.speaker: Socr.
sp.l: Away and take him with you.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: IO my son! O how I joy to see
Thy chang'd complexion! Thou lookst now me thinks
As if thou wert inspir'd with contradiction
I read, • erosse questions in thy very face,
Thy very eyes me thinks say, how, how's that?
Thou canst perswade the world that thou art wrong'd,
When thou art, he that does the wrong. I see't,
Now let it be thy study to recover
Him, whom thou almost hast undone,

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: Why, what
Is that you fear?

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: The old and the new day.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: Can one and the same day be old and new?

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: I know that: I'm sure my Creditors
By joint consent that day threaten to sue me.

sp.speaker: Phi • .
sp.l: They'l loose by it if they do: for 'tis impossible
To make two daies of one.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: How is't impossible?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: As for a woman to be old and young
At once.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: But law has so determined it

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: But these men know not what the law doth mean.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Why what's the meaning of it.

l.note: See the life of Solon. Ch • p.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Antient Solon
Was naturally a lover of the people.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: What's that to this?

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: He did appoint two daies,
The last day of the old month for citation,
The first oth' new for payment of the money.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: But why the last day for citations?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: That
The debtor having thus one day of warning
Might fly and shun the trouble of the next.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Why do the Magistrates then take all forfeits
Upon the old and new day?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: They are hungry,
And tast their meat before they should fall too.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: We the fools that sit still and do nothing,
We that are wise and quick have done the businesse;
Ye blocks, ye stones, ye sheep, ye empty bubbles;
Let me congratulate this son of min
My selfe and my good fortune in a song.
Now Strepsiades th'art blest
Of the most discreet the best,
What a Son thou hast, now may
All my aemulous neighbours say,
When they hear that he alone
Hath my creditours orethrown.
But come my boy, now thou shalt feast with me,

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: ANd must a man be outed of his own thus?
Better take any course then suffer this.
You must assist me in this businesse neighbour,
That I may call my debtor to accompt;
There's one friend made a foe; yet I'le not shame
My country, ere I do't, I'le give him warning.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: How now, what would you have?

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: The old and new daies come.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Bear witnesse friend,
He nam'd two daies. What summe is't you demand.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Twelve pounds you borrow'd when you bought your
Son
A Race-horse; with the interest.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: A race-horse,
You know I neer car'd for'em in my life.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: And swor'st by Iove and all the Gods to pay it.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: By Iove? 'twas then before my son had learn't
The all-convincing speech.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: You'l not deny't.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: What have I got but that, for all this learning?

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Darst thou deny't, if I should put thee to
Thy oath, and make thee call the Gods to witness it?

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: What Gods de'e mean?

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Iove, Mercury, and Neptune.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: By Iove? yes that I will I hold thee three pence.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Curse on thee for this impudence.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: If thou wert rubb'd with salt, 'twould make thy wit
the quicker.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: De'laugh at me?

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Thou wilt take up six bushells.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: So help me Iupiter, and all the Gods,
I will even be with you for this scorn.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: I am extreamly taken with your Gods,

And this same Iupiter •
you swear by, they
Are excellent pastime to a knowing man.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Well, you will one day answer for these words.
But tell me, whether I shall have my money
Or not, give my answer, and I'me gone.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Stay but a little, I will answer presently,
And plainly.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Sure hee's gone to fetch the mony

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Where is the Man that comes to ask me mony?
Tell me, what's this?

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: That which it is, a Cardopus.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: You ask for mony, and so very a dunce;
I'le never whilst I live pay him a penny.
That calls a Cardopa a Cardopus.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: You will not pay then?

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Not for ought I know:
You'l stay no longer, pray about your businesse.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Yes, I'le be gone, but in the mean time know
I'le have my mony, if I live this day.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: You may chance go without it; yet I'm sorry
You should be punish'd so for a mistake.
For saying Cardopus for Cardopa.

sp.speaker: Amyn.
sp.l: OH, oh, alasse.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Who's that keeps such a bawling?
What art thou? one ofWhich were Xenocles, Xenotimus, and D • motimus, •• agick • oets and Actors. Carkinus his sons?

sp.speaker: Amyn.
sp.l: 'Tis I unhappy!

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Keep it to thy selfe.

sp.speaker: Amyn.
sp.l: Unlucky chance, oh cruell destiny,
To spoil at once my Cart and all my Horses •
This and the following line are takes from Xenocles the Tragadian, which is the reason of Strepsiades his answer. Oh Pallas, how unkindly hast thou us'd me?

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: What hurt did ere Tlepolemus do thee?

sp.speaker: Amyn.
sp.l: Deride me not, but rather bid your son
Pay me the mony which he had of me,
For I was never in more need of it.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: What mony man?

sp.speaker: Amyn.
sp.l: That which he borrowed of me.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Then I perceive you're in a sad condition.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I had a scurvy fall driving my horses.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Thou dost but jest, 'twas driving an Asse rather.

sp.speaker: Amyn.
sp.l: I do not jest when I demand my mony.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Upon my word thou art not right.

sp.speaker: Amyn.
sp.l: How so?

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Thy brain me thinks is troubled.

sp.speaker: Amyn.
sp.l: E • ther pay me
My money strait, or I will trouble you.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Tell me, doth Iove beget and send down rain.
Or doth the Sun exhale it from the sea?

sp.speaker: Amyn.
sp.l: I neither know nor care.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: What? are you sit
To receive mony, and so ignorant
Of these sublime and subtle mysteries?

sp.speaker: Amyn.
sp.l: Well, if you cannot let me have the principal,
Pay me the interest.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Interest, what kind
Of creature's that?

sp.speaker: Amyn.
sp.l: What, but th'encrease of mony
By months, and daies, as time runs on.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: 'Tis well.
And do you think the sea is fuller now
Then 'twas at first?

sp.speaker: Amyn.
sp.l: No, not a drop, it is
Not fit it should.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: The sea by your confession
Is nothing grown; then with what conscience
Can you desire your mony should encrease.
Go get you from my doores, fetch me a whip there.

sp.speaker: Witn.
sp.l: Well, I'le bear witnesse for him.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Why de'e not go, will you moveThe Horses name which he bought of him. Samphoras?

sp.speaker: Amyn.
sp.l: Is not this riotous?

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Will you be gone?
Or shall I lead you in a chain, and make you
Shew tricks? if you but stay a little longer,
I'le send you, and your Cart and Horses packing.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.l: "Now observe what 'tis to bend
"Studies to an evill end
"This old man, that is intent
"Creditours to circumvent,
"Foolishly himselfe hath crost,
"And will find so to his cost;
"That in this false Art his son
"Hath attain'd perfection:
"Justice cunning to refute)
"That at last hee'l wish him mute.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: O Neighbours, Kinsmen, Countrymen, help, help,
I'm beat all all over: oh my head, my back •
Thou strik'st thy Father Rogue.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: I do so father.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: See, see, he stands in't too.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: I do indeed.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Thief, villain, Patricide.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: More I beseech you,
I am much taken with these pretty Titles.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Rascall,

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: Pray stick me fuller of these roses:

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Dost beat thy Father?

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: Yes, by Iove, and justly.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Oh' rogue what justice can there be in that.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: I will demonstrate it by argument.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: By argument?

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: Most easily, which language
Shall I dispute in.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Language?

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: Yes the greater
Or lesser?

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: I have bred thee well indeed
If thou canst make this good, that any son
May beat his Father.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: You'l confesse as much
If I so prove it, that you cannot answer't.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Well, I will hear for once what you can say.

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: "OLd man it much concerns you to confute
"Your son, whose confidence appears to suit
"With a just cause; how happen'd this dispute?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: I shall relate it from the first; as soon
As we had din'd, I took a lute and bid him
Sing the sheep-shearing of Simonides,
He told me 'twas an old and ugly fashio •
To sing at dinner like a millers wife.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: And was not this sufficient to deserve
A beating; when you'd make men chirp likeAt noon Virgecl. 2.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Just so he said within; and added that
Simonides was an unpleasant Poet.
I must confesse I hardly could forbear him;
But then I bid him take a Myrtle, branch,
And act some piece of Aeschylus, that Aechylus
Saith he, is of all Poets the absurdest,
The harshest, most disorderly and bumbast.
Did not my heart pant at this language think you?
Yet I represt it; Then said I, rehearse
A learned speech out of some modern wit;
He strait repeats out of Euripides
A tedious long Oration, how the Brother
(Good Heavens) did violate his sisters bed.
Here I confesse I could contain no longer
But chid him sharply; to dispute we went,
Words upon words till he at last to blowes,
To strike, to pull, to tear me.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: And not justly?
You that would discommend Euripides,
The wisest of all Poets.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Wisest? ah
What did I say, I shall be beat agen.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: By Iove, and you deserve't.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: How, deserve it?
Ungratefull wretch, have I not brought thee up,
Fed and maintain'd thee from a little one,
Supplied thy wants? how then can I deserve it?

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.l: "Now I believe each youthfull breast
"With expectation possest,
"That if the glory of the day
"Be from the Plantiffe born away,
"By this example they may all
"Upon the old men heavy fall;
"What you have done with utmost art,
"To justifie is now your part.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: How sweet it is to study, sage new things;
And to contemn all fundamental lawes!
When I applied my mind to Horse-coursing
I could not speak three words but I was out;
Now since I gave it one, I am acquainted
With ponderous sentences and subtle reasons,
Able to prove I ought to beat my Father.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Nay, follow racing still, for I had rather
Maintain thy horses then be beaten thus.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: I will begin where you did interrupt me,
And first will ask, did you not beat me when
I was a child?

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: But that was out of love.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: 'Tis very right, tell me then, ought not I
To recompence your love with equall love;
If to be beaten be to be belov'd,
Why should I suffer stripes, and you have none?
I am by nature born as free as you;
Nor is it fit the sons should be chastiz'd,
and not their parents.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: You urge the Law,
That doth allow all children to be beaten:
To which I answer, Old men are twice children.
And therefore ought, when they offend, be punish'd
As well as we,

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: But there's no Law that saies
The Parents should be punished.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: Was not he
Who made that Law, a man as you and I,
He form'd a Law, which all the old men follow'd;
Why may not I as well prescribe another,
And all the young men follow my advice:
But all the blowes before this Law was made
Must be forgiven wihtout all dispute.
Besides, mark how the Cocks and other creatures
Fight with their sires, who differ not at all
From us, save only that they make no lawes.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Why then if you will imitate the Cocks,
Do you not dine upon a Dunghill, and
Lodge in a hen-roost?

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: 'Tis not all one case,
Our Socrates doth not approve so far.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Approve not then their sighting, but in this
Thou plead'st against thy selfe.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: How so?

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Because
Th'authority I exercise o're thee
Will be thine own, when ere thou hast a son.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: But if I ne'r have any, then I never
Shall have authority, and you will go
To th'grave deriding me.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: 'Tis too much reason.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: Hear now another argument.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: I'me lost.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: And then perhaps you'l take the blowes I gave you
Not halfe so ill.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: What good shall I get by them?

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: I'le bent my mother too.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: What sayest thou, thou?
Why this is worse then t'other.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: What if I
Prove by the second language that I ought?

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Why then you will have nothing more to do
But prove that you, and your wise Socrates,
And wiser language may hang all together.
O Clouds, all this I suffer through your means,
For I in you wholly repos'd my trust.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.l: "Thy selfe art author of this misery,
"Because to ill thou didst thy mind apply.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Why did you then give me no warning of it?
You know I was a rude and aged man.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.l: "This is our custome, whensoere we find
"Any to malice or deceit enclin'd,
"Into some dreadful mischief such we thrust,
"That they may fear the Gods, and learn what's just.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Alasse, this is a mischief, and a just one,
For I ought not, when I had borrow'd mony,
To seek out wayes t'avoid restoring it.
Come then my son, let us be reveng'd
Upon that wicked Socrates and Ch •• raephon,
Who have abus'd us both.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: I will not wrong
My Masters.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Reverence Celestiall Iove.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: Celestiall Iove, see how you rave now father▪
There's no such thing as Iove.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: There is.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: Act. 3. A whirle-wind
Hath blown Iove quite away, and rules all.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: No son, he's not expell'd, I was but fool'd
To worhip in his room a fictile deity.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.l: Nay if you will needs be mad, be mad alone.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: MAd that I was to trust in Socrates,
And cast off all our Gods; good Mercury
Be not displeas'd or punish, but forgive me.
That took such paines, and studied to talk idly;
And tell me what I'de best do with these fellowes.
Sue them or punish'em some other way—
Th'art in the right, I will not sue them then,
But as thou bidst me set their Nest on fire;
Come Xanthias, come, a fork and ladder quickly.
Get up and pluck the house about their Ears,
Quick if thou lovest thy master; one of you
Go light a torch, and bring it hither strait:
Proud as they are I mean to bring'em lower,

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: OH, oh!

sp.speaker: Strep.
sp.l: Torch to thy work, set fire apace.

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: What art thou doing man?

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: That which I'm doing;
Disputing somewhat hotly with your school here.

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: Alasse, who's this that sets our house on fire?

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: He whom you cosen'd of his cloak.

sp.speaker: Schol.
sp.l: Thou kill'st,
Thou kil'lst us man.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: That is the thing I mean,
If my fork hold and ladder, do not fail me.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: How now, what do you make on our house-ridge.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Act. 2. 〈◊〉 . 3. I walk i'th air and gaze upon the Sun.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Alasse I'm choak'd.

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Why dost thou scorn the Gods then?

sp.speaker: Chaer.
sp.l: Oh me I burn;

sp.speaker: Streps.
sp.l: Now you may • calculate
The motions of the Moon; tear, pluck, beat, burn'em.
For many reasons they deserve the flame,
But most because they did the Gods disclaim.

div.head: CHAP. I.
Xenophon, his Country Parents, and following of Socrates.
div.p: Xenophon was an Atheni • n,Lae •• . son of Cryllus, of the Erchiean Tribe: The time of his birth is no where expressely delivered:Laert. Stesiclides affirms he died the first year of the 105. Olympiad. de Longave. Lucian that he outlived 90. years: whence it is evident that hee was born at or before the first year of the 82. Olympiad, which if the learned Causabone had observed, he had notAnima •• . • . 12. alter'd Athenaeus upon supposition, that he was but ten years old, the fourth year of the 89. Olympiad (the time of his Symposium) whereas he was then no lesse then 36. years of age. Laertius saith, he flourished the fourth year of the 94. Olympiad. (Suidas reads, of the 98.) Or, according to others, that he flourished in the 89. Olympiad with the rest of the Socratick Philosophers; of whom he became one upon this accident.

In the time of that great war betwixt the Lacedaemonians and Athenians, called the Peloponnesian war (the naturall forwardnesse of his spirit being perhaps excited by the example of his Master Socrates) hee was personally engaged in the fight before Delium, the first year of the 89. Olympiad • wherein the Boeotians overcame the Athenians; in which defeatStrab. 9. Laert. Xenophon in the flight unhorsed and thrown, down, Socrates (who his horse being likewise slain under him, fought on foot) took him upon his shoulders and and carried him many furlongs, untill the Enemy gave over the pursuit. This was the first essay of his military profession, which he afterward resum'd upon this occasion.

div.head: CHAP. 2.
Vpon what occasion he followed Cyrus into Asia.
div.p: Xenoph. expedit cyr. lib. 1. ARtaxerxes succeeded Darius his Father in the Kingdom of Persia, Cyrus his younger brother having been sent for out of his Government of Lyd • a upon his fathers sicknesse, which is that first 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 placed by the Arundelian stone in the second year of the 93. Olympiad, confounded byAd Gre • . Epoch. c • n. Chron. pag. 113. a learned person with the latter, six years after) was imprison'd by his brother upon the accusation of Tissaphernes, but released by the mediation of his Mother Parysa • is. Being returned to his Government, he used all secret means to strengthen himselfe. the Ionian Cities were delivered to Tissaphernes by Artaxerxes, but revolted to him, all except Myletus. His pretences for levying forces were, the Garrisoning of those Cities, and his opposing Tissaphernes: Clearchus likewise raised for him many in Chersonesus, upon pretence of warring against the Thracians. He privately also kept an Army on foot in Thessaly under Aristippus: and Proxenus of Boeotia brought him forces as against the Pisidians; this Proxenus (who had been scholar to Gorgias the Leontine, andXen. lib. 3. guest to Xenophon) sent to invite him to Cyrus, assuring him he should be of more esteem with him then of his own Country: Xenophon consulted with Socrates about this letter, who doubting that if he took part with Cyrus, the Athenians would be disples'd with him (Cyrus having before aided the Lacedemonians against them) counsell'd him to ask the advice of the Delphian Oracle. Xenophon went thither, and demanded of Apollo to which of the Gods he should address his vowes and sacrifice for the good successe of his intended journey. Hee was answer'd, that he should sacrifice to those Gods to whom it was due: Returning to Athens, he imparted this Oracle to Socrates, who blam'd him, because he had not demanded whether it was best to stay or no, but (as already determined to goe) how he might best perform his journey; Neverthelesse (saith he) since you have so proposed your demand, you must do as the Gods command: Xenophon having sacrificed according to the Oracles direction, took shipping, and at Sardis found Proxenus and Cyrus ready for their expedition into Asia, and was immediately recommended to Cyrus, being by both earnestly intreated to stay: hee continued with himXen. lib. 3. not in any command, but as a volunteer,Chio. Epist. ad Metrid. In which condition he did not any thing misbeseeming a souldier, whereupon he was in the number of those whom Cyrus esteem'd most.

Xenoph. lib. 1. Cyrus having drawn all his forces together, marched up and
gave battle to Artax • rxes (in the beginning of the fourth yearLaert. of the nintie fourth Olympiad, when Xenenetus was Archon) at Cunaxa, five hundred Stadia from Babylon, by the River Euphrates. Whilst he was viewing both Armies, he told Xenophon, who rode up to him, that the sacrifices were auspicious; then Xenophon gave him the Grecians word, Iupiter the pres • ruer. The Greeks prevailed against Tissaphernes; but Cyrus assaulting, the King, was through his too much forwardnesse • lain; the Grecians thinking themselves Masters of the field, and Cyrus to be alive, returned to their Camp, which they found rif • ed by the enemy.Xenoph. lib. 2. The next day the King sending Phalinus to them, to deliver their armes, Xenophon answered, That they had • nothing left but their armes and valour; as long as they kept their armes, they might use their valour, surrendring them, they were not Masters of themselves; It were indiscretion (saith he) to surrender what we have left, since thereby perhaps we may make our selves Masters of what you have. Phalinus smiling, replyed; Young man, you look and speak like a Philosopher; but assure your selfe, your valour will not over-master the Kings power. Clearchus returned this answer for the whole Army, If we be esteemed friends, it will be better for him that we are armed, if enemies, better for our selves. Tissaphernes having made a Truce with Clearchus, perfidiously got him with foure other Commanders, Proxenus, Menon, (Laert. with whom Xenophon had particular enmity) Agias, and Socrates, twenty Captains of Cohorts, and two hundred common souldiers into his power; and delivering them up to the King, they were beheaded. The Greeks being summoned to lay down their armes, pretending that Clearchus was executed for treason discovered by Menon and Proxenus, who were very highly rewarded. Xenophon required to have them sent, who were fittest to direct them, being friends to both; whereto the Persians not able to answer, departed.

div.head: CHAP. III.
How he brought off the Grecian Army.
div.p:
Xe • ph. lib. 3; THe Greeks finding themselves in such a strait, were in despair ever to see their Country again. Xenophon calling together the Officers of Proxenus, told them, They were not to expect any mercy from the King, who had shewen none to the body of his dead brother, having fastned his head and hand to a Gibbet, and that they must reslove to put their safetie in their armes. Apollonides a B • eotian alledg'd, that there was no means of safety but in the Kings favour
and began to reckon the dangers wherewith they were surrounded. Xenophon answered. That when upon the death of Cyrus, they marched up to the Kings armies, he laboured for a cessation, but when their Captains went to him unarmed, he abused them; and that Apollonides deserved to be cashierd, as the dishonour of his Nation. Agasthias replyed, (which words Laertius ascribes to Xenophon) he was an inconsiderable fellow, whose ears were boared as the slaves of Lydia: So they turned him out. Having called together all the Commanders, Xenophon advised them to chuse new in the room of those that were lost, of whom he was elected in the place of Proxenus: Hereupon he put on his richest habit, as fittest either for death or victory, forAelian. var. hist. 3. 24. his greatest delight was in fair polished armes, affirming, that if he overcame, he deserved such, if he were overcome and died in the field, they would decently expresse his quality, and were the fittest sepulchrall ornaments of a valiant man. His shield was of Argos, his breastplate of Altica, his helmet of B • eotia, his horse of Epidaurium; whereby Aelian argued the elegance of the person, in choosing such things as were fair, and esteeming him worthy of such. Thus adorned, he made an oration to the Army, advising them (from the examples of their late commanders) not to trust the enemy, but in order to their return, to burn their Cariages, and Tents: this advice was put in execution; Cherisophus a Lacedaemonian had charge of the Van, Xenophon of the Reer, chosen (saith) Chio as well for his courage as wisdome, being in both excellent: betwixt these two there grew so great a friendship, that in all the time of the retreat they never had but one difference; their march was directed towards the heads of those great rivers which lay in their way, that they might passe them where they were fordable; having crost the River Zathe, Mithridates came up to them, and galled the Reer with shot, which the Greeks not able to requite, Xenophon provided two hundred slings, and finding fifty horses fit for service, imployed among the Carriage, mounted men upon them, whereby having frustrated the second attempt of Mithridates, they marched to Larissa, seated upon Tigris, thence to Mespila; in their march from thence, Tissaphernes overtook them with a great Army, but was twice worsted; whereupon (as the securest course) he seized on a Mountain, under which they must of necessity passe; Xenophon with a party gained by another way the top of that Mountain, not without much difficulty of passage and trouble; and to animate his souldiers, one of them, named Soteridas, murmured that he was on horse-back, whereas himselfe marched on foot, opprest with the weight of his shield; which Xenophon hearing, alighted, took his shield from him, and thrusting him out of his rank, marched (notwithstanding
he had also a horse-man Cuirasse) in his room: But the souldiers beat and reviled Soteridas, till they constrained him to take again his shield and place. When they had gained the top, the enemy, being prevented fled, and set fire on the villages.Xenoph. lib. 4. The Grecians, (intercepted by the River Tigris) marched over the mountains into the Country of the Carduchi, a people enemy to the Persians, rough and warlike, from whom they found such opposition, that in seven daies march through their country, they were put to continuall fights, and suffered more distresses then the Persian had put them to, Fording the River K • ntrites, which bounds that country, they passed into Armenia, where having put to flight some troops of horse raised by the Kings deputies in these parts to oppose their passage, they marched without disturbance to the heads of Tigris, which they passed; thence to the River of Tele • od in west Armenia, molested with extream snowes, losing many by extremity of cold, till they came to the River Phasis, neer which lived the Phasiani, Tacc • i, and the Chalybes; the Tacchi into whose country they first came, conveying their provision into strong holds, reduced the Greeks to great want, untill with much paines they forced one of them, where they took as much Cattle as maintained them in their passage through the country of the Chalybes, a stout Nation, of whom they could get nothing but blowes: thence they marched to the River Harpasus, so to the Scy • hini, where the Lord of Gymnias, a town in those parts, led them through the enemies country (which he willed them to burn as they went) to the Mountain Theches • , from whence they might behold the sea, to the great joy of the souldiers. Passing friendly through the country of the Macrones, to the Colchian Mountains, discom • iting the Colchi, who opposed them, they arived at T • aprezond, a City upon the Euxine sea, where was a Greek Colony; here they sacrificed and celebrated games:Xenoph. lib. • . Cherisophus they sent to Anaxibius, the Lacedaemonian Admirall, (with whom he was intimate) to procure ships for their transportation home. Whilest they stayed in expectation of his return, they maintained themselves by incursions upon the Colchi and Dryla • ; but he not coming, and their provision failing, Xenophon perswaded the Cities adjoyning to cleer them a passage by Land, which they took to Cerasus a Greek City, where mustering their men, they found but eight thousand six hundred left of ten thousand that went up with Cyrus; the rest consumed by enemies, snow, and sicknesse: They shared the mony that had been made by the sale of Captives, reserving a tenth for a offering to Apollo and Diana: Xenophon reserved his to be disposed at Delphi and Ephesus, From Cerasus they passed through the Country of the Mosyna • ci, a barbarous people, divided into factions; the stronger part despising their
friendship, they joyned with the weaker, whom they left Master of all: Then they marched to the Chalybes, thence to the Tibarenes, passing quietly through their Country to Cotyora, a Greek Town and Colony of the Sinopians Thus far the Army marched on foot; the distance of the place where they fought with Artax • rxes to Cotyora, being one hundred twenty two encampings, six hundred twenty parasangs, ten thousand eight hundred twenty furlongs, the time eight Months.
